awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Advanced anode material for lithium-ion batteries based on filled carbon nanotubes
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project will be in the improvement of lithium-ion batteries (LIBs).  Current LIBs are often limited in energy density and charging speed due to their graphite anode.  These limits result in larger sizes and weights of LIBs for advanced applications such as long-range electric vehicles (EVs). The proposed technology involves a novel nanomaterial, nickel sulfide-filled carbon nanotubes, that can replace the conventional graphite anode and enhance the performance of LIBs.  This innovation can alleviate the aforementioned problems in current anode technologies and can enable development of the next generation of high performance LIBs for EVs, grid energy storage, and electric aviation. By enabling wider adoption of LIB technologies, this project can help reduce emissions linked to climate change.

This I-Corps project will advance the knowledge in the fundamental electrochemical properties of metal sulfide-filled carbon nanotubes. Specifically, the team will help to understand how the solid core-shell structure affects the transport of electrons and lithium ions and how the volume expansion of the lithiated nanowire filler is accommodated by the carbon shells. The expected results will provide new insight into the electrochemical properties of carbon nanotubes filled with metal sulfide nanowires in lithium-ion battery (LIB) applications. In this project, nanomaterials of nickel sulfide filled carbon nanotubes are developed together with techniques to synthesize these materials on flexible carbon cloth.  These nanomaterials have been shown to exhibit energy storage capacity which is several times that of the current commercial graphite anode materials. Further, the nanomaterials have shown exceptional charging-discharging stability.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The project aims to achieve three major goals. Firstly, the project includes conducting customer discovery to validate and invalidate our business model canvas hypotheses and developing strategies for commercializing our lab invention: nickel sulfide-filled carbon nanotubes (Ni3S2@CNTs). Secondly, it involves innovating the synthesis technique of the Ni3S2@CNTs and studying the fundamental electrochemical properties of the material. Thirdly, the project provides the EL with entrepreneurship training opportunities.

The project team has participated in the national I-Corps program and conducted a total of 101 customer discovery interviews. Before the national I-Corps program, the project team thought of the final product being the anode material of lithium-ion batteries (LIBs); however, the I-Corps activities made the team pivot from the original product being only anode material to products being both anode material and anode additives for LIBs. The pivot was made based on the outcomes of the customer discovery interviews. After the NSF I-Corps cohort workshop, the team has also talked with about 90 people at the battery shows/seminars/exhibits to further validate our business model canvas. The interviewees included potential customers in the LIB industries, electric vehicle companies, battery material manufacturers, potential partners, etc.  

The project team has innovated the material synthesis technique and investigated the material's lithium storage behavior. In addition, the team has studied the material's electrocatalytic behavior to explore its electrochemical properties further. The research has resulted in three peer-reviewed publications, one manuscript submitted for review, and one manuscript in preparation. In addition, the first EL, a graduate student, has completed his dissertation on the work related to this project.  

The two Els of our NSF I-Corps team have received entrepreneurship training. The first EL (who already graduated with his Ph.D. degree from the Department of Physics at FIU) successfully led our NSF I-Corps team to complete the NSF I-Corps cohort training and interviewed 101 customers. The second EL (a current Ph.D. student at FIU) led the further customer discovery and R&D processes. The industrial mentor (IM) of our I-Corps team provided the ELs with his industrial perspective on the R&D outcomes and market fit of our inventions. The ELs have participated in the entrepreneurship training workshops/presentations offered by the StartUP FIU office to learn the fundamentals of translating laboratory inventions to commercialization and opportunities to become entrepreneurs.

 


Last Modified: 02/03/2024
Modified by: Wenzhi Li
